title: BlackRock’s ‘Bumpier’ Quarter Fuels Poor Earnings

rawLines.text:
I think we can break it down into three
main areas.

The first is there was a large client
redemption in the quarter, a $52 billion

client redemption from one client.
I think that spooked investors.

Redemptions tend to do that and that
masked some otherwise really good fund

flow trends.
The second thing I think that also

spooked investors because the entire
group is off today was the higher than

expected inflation number, particularly
as we're likely to head into a summer

where tariffs are going to probably
potentially boost that number higher

and, you know, long dated assets and
highly correlated assets like those at

BlackRock are vulnerable.
Stocks are vulnerable to a correction

when that happens.
And then I think the third factor that

drove today's performance was, for lack
of a better word, the noise around all

of the acquisitions that BlackRock has
done.

Having said all that, I am still
positive on the shares.

It's the world's largest money manager.
It's certainly known over the last

couple of decades for the growth that
it's seen when it comes to ETFs, and

that's certainly Emily Fayose's
specialty in her coverage here as a

cross asset.
REPORTER But BlackRock is going through

this transformation right now, private
markets, infrastructure.

What is its identity and how has it
communicated that to investors?

That's a really good question because I
think some of the shortfall today may

have been investors sort of digesting
all these changes and also some of the

execution risk inherent in that
strategy.

I mean, I do like the strategy and I
think BlackRock has these sort of three

pillars of growth.
One is the ETFs, as you mentioned.

The other is their technology business,
which is there is a secular shift among

a lot of
in the asset management space that's

driving demand for BlackRock's
technology services.

And then the third leg to this strategy,
which I think to your point, that

perhaps BlackRock needs to perhaps be a
little more granular in the strategy,

you know, maybe
highlight or elevate some of the people

driving the strategy, and that is their
shift into private assets and

alternative assets.
I think it's an important shift for

BlackRock and I think it's one that will
offer support to the shares valuation,

but I think it's one that has, number
one, some execution risk.

And number two is likely to make 2025 a
transitional year for the firm.

Talk a little bit more about BlackRock's
push here into private markets.

Just how critical is it that they get
this right and the earnings that we've

seen so far, this report today, did it
tell us anything about how successful

this push into alternatives has been so
far?

Sure.
So, you know, one of the challenges,

given that given BlackRock's size,
moving the needle is going to be a

challenge.
That's number one.

I mean, we saw the asset, the a, um,
number 12 and a half trillion dollars.

A lot of it is in ETFs or in
institutionally managed assets.

And so the push to alternatives is
likely to take some time.

I mean, BlackRock's aspirational goal is
to have 30% of revenues coming from

technology and alternatives by 2030.
It's about last year, I think it was

about 14 or 15%.
So, you know, we can sort of hang our

hat on that number.
I think the other thing to remember is

this strategy and I applaud this
strategy.

I do think it makes a lot of sense.
They have sort of and I'm going to say

cobbled together and there shouldn't be
a negative connotation with that.

They've sort of assembled a group of
companies and built themselves a

pipeline through which they will be able
to push more product.

And by that, I mean buying global
infrastructure partners gives them

exposure to infrastructure, gives them
exposure to private credit.

Those are very important because the
demand for both of those assets is

expected to continue to grow,
particularly among institutional pension

funds, life insurance companies.
That's a secular shift and it's an

important it's an important part of the
market.

And I applaud the fact that BlackRock is
expanding its reach in that area.

I have to get an ETF question in here
because like Tim said, this is part of

my focus on the cross as a team at
Bloomberg News.

So BlackRock has more total ETF assets
than Vanguard.

But when it comes to flows.
Vanguard has taken in more ETF inflows

for the last five years than BlackRock.
And I'm wondering if you think this is

something that keeps Larry Fink up at
night, this potential that Vanguard is

going to overtake BlackRock in total ETF
assets.

Is this something that is important to
BlackRock and is it something that

you're watching?
Well, I mean, definitely I think the ETF

marketplace represents of BlackRock's
ETF franchise is an attractive

franchise, but I think growth there is
going to be a challenge.

I mean, the market, you know, they're
the leader.

I would also point out, though, that
BlackRock's lineup of ETFs has a greater

representation in some of the faster
growing areas, digital assets and

things, you know, alternatives, things
like that.

So while perhaps overall flows at
Vanguard may be more than at BlackRock,

they're flowing into some very low fee
generating businesses.

And one of the strategies at BlackRock
is to have a shift to assets that

generate a greater revenue or, you know,
a higher higher fee earning assets.

So I think the focus at BlackRock is to
obviously maintain their dominance in

the ETF market space, continue to
innovate there, which they have done,

but at the same time push into areas
where there still is a degree of, let's

just say pricing power on the part of
the asset manager.

Hey, just 30 seconds, 20 seconds on on
its identity.

If we think about peers out there,
Vanguard, certainly one that Emily

thinks a lot about, what about like a
capital group?

What are the other companies that you
think are or maybe in Apollo these days

like what is a a peer now to BlackRock?
Well, that's interesting because I sort

of would put, you know, if you look at
again, I'm an equity analyst, and so my

primary focus in terms of valuation is
on the other publicly traded asset

managers.
And it's a very bifurcated group.

If you look at the way the for example,
the way S&P classifies the asset

management group on one end of the
spectrum in terms of valuation, you have

the private equity firms, Blackstone,
KKR and Apollo sort of sitting right in

the middle of that.
You have BlackRock.

And then at the other end of the
spectrum, you know, BlackRock with, you

know, primarily a personal asset manager
shifting.

And then at the other end of the
spectrum, you have a number of the
primarily active managers.

The first is there was a large client redemption in the quarter, a $52 billion client redemption from one client.
I think that spooked investors.
Redemptions tend to do that and that masked some otherwise really good fund flow trends.
The second thing I think that also spooked investors because the entire group is off today was the higher than expected inflation number, particularly as we're likely to head into a summer where tariffs are going to probably potentially boost that number higher and, you know, long dated assets and highly correlated assets like those at BlackRock are vulnerable.
Stocks are vulnerable to a correction when that happens.
And then I think the third factor that drove today's performance was, for lack of a better word, the noise around all of the acquisitions that BlackRock has done.
Having said all that, I am still positive on the shares.
It's the world's largest money manager.
It's certainly known over the last couple of decades for the growth that it's seen when it comes to ETFs, and that's certainly Emily Fayose's specialty in her coverage here as a cross asset.

I think it's an important shift for BlackRock and I think it's one that will offer support to the shares valuation, but I think it's one that has, number one, some execution risk.
And number two is likely to make 2025 a transitional year for the firm.
Talk a little bit more about BlackRock's push here into private markets.

And I applaud the fact that BlackRock is expanding its reach in that area.
